children.subject:
I'm not sure whether this answers your question since these classes are co-listed.  Yes the undergrads can 'take' the grad versions of the same class if thats what you mean. The class is basically a mix of grad and undergrad students. I took 151, 127, and 106A last semester which were co-listed as graduate classes. 

151 (lecture content) practically had no difference in terms of homework apart from the 251A students having to solve maybe 1 additional subpart of a question in 2 homeworks out of 11. The exams were also pretty much 90% identical apart from 2 additional subproblems (in the entire test not per problem) the graduate students have to solve. The 151 lab was practically the same until the project where in the end, the graduate students were expected to implement about 20% more than the undergraduate requirements. Wasn't that much more difficult having read what they had to do. 

127/227 practically had 0 difference last semester in any way or form. I heard some semesters the graduate version would have a optimisation projects as additional work but when I took it last semester, there was no difference.

106A/206A practically also had 0 difference last semester.

history.content: Depend on the professor teaching the class and you should ask them. Most of the time undergrad enrolling in grad class is 100% up to the professor teaching. If you have a good reason, they'll let you enroll. Though if a class has both an undergrad and grad version, they are usually identical except for a final research project.
Can undergrads take grad versions of the same class if they are willing to do additional assignments? What is really the difference?
history.subject: Undergrad Courses with Grad Version (e.g. EECS 151 is equivalent to EECS 251A)
